SENT.plain: OBJECTIVES: perioperative stroke reduces the clinical effectiveness of carotid endarterectomy (CEA)
Postoperative thrombotic stroke may be reduced in incidence by the use of transcranial Doppler-directed Dextran-40 therapy
This programme requires the purchase of additional equipment and employment of more staff
This study examined whether this additional financial outlay was cost-effective in terms of saving expenditure by preventing postoperative thrombotic stroke
MATERIALS AND METHODS: data was collected prospectively on a series of 600 consecutive CEAs
The costs of the monitoring programme were analysed over 1- and 5-year periods
Formulae were derived allowing other units to calculate whether this technique will be cost-effective for them
RESULTS: after the introduction of TCD monitoring the postoperative thrombotic stroke rate fell from 2.7% to 0% (8 strokes prevented)
Our local unit cost for the treatment of stroke was 25,702 pounds
After allowing for the additional costs of the monitoring programme, we calculate that postoperative TCD has saved 171,393 pounds
CONCLUSIONS: postoperative TCD monitoring is a clinically effective and also cost-effective method of reducing the stroke rate associated with CEA
For units performing more than 50 CEAs per year who experience occasional postoperative carotid thrombosis, its introduction should be considered
